awd_titl_txt: Sophomore Fellows: Cultivating New Scientists through Research, Mentoring, and Community
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Sophomore Fellows project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at the University of Texas at Austin. Throughout its five years of funding, this project will fund 125 annual scholarships of up to $5,000 for sophomore students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in Astronomy, Biology, Biochemistry, Chemistry, Computer Sciences, and Physics. The Sophomore Fellows project will engage these Scholars in research projects that are situated in a community of undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty mentors. The goal of the Sophomore Fellows project is to increase persistence and graduation rates of low-income students, including those from groups that are underrepresented in STEM, while better preparing students for graduate school and scientific careers. 

This project will investigate the efficacy of coupling financial aid with intra-curricular research, faculty mentorship, and peer mentoring activities to improve student academic growth and persistence. Sophomore Fellows leverages the Freshman Research Initiative (FRI) in the College of Natural Sciences at UT Austin. FRI is a community-based curriculum-integrated program that engages undergraduate students in research. The Sophomore Fellows project will use the existing FRI program structure, which has been demonstrated to increase graduation rates in STEM, and will add a financial incentive to encourage students to persist at the most common attrition point between their first and second years. Sophomore Fellows will take courses in an FRI research stream. A research group that includes faculty, graduate students, and other undergraduates, will form the structure for this research experience. It is expected that this experience will help students develop skills including teamwork, research, writing, and oral communication.  In their second semester, Sophomore Fellows will serve as peer mentors for incoming FRI students, amplifying the impact of these scholarships to dozens of students for every award given.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: UT Austin S-STEM Sophomore Fellows Program 2018-2023

Introduction
The S-STEM Sophomore Fellows Program at the University of Texas at Austin College of Natural Sciences was designed to address barriers faced by low-income students in pursuing STEM degrees and to provide support and incentivize retention past a critical sophomore-year attrition point. By offering financial scholarships, research opportunities, and professional development, the program aimed to foster student success, increase retention in STEM fields, and contribute to a well-prepared STEM workforce. Over five years, this program provided unique opportunities for 132 students, equipping them with skills and experiences essential for their academic and professional growth.

Outcomes and Findings

Intellectual Merit
The program demonstrated the importance of combining financial support with structured mentorship and research experiences in improving STEM retention and academic performance. Students participating in the program consistently exhibited higher retention and graduation rates compared to their peers. Specifically, S-STEM Fellows achieved a 99% retention rate in STEM disciplines between their first and second years, higher than the comparison group’s 93%. Fellows also had stronger four- and five-year graduation rates, with up to a 17% improvement over their peers.

Through intensive mentorship training, leadership seminars, and hands-on research, Fellows developed critical skills in scientific communication, leadership, and collaboration. By participating in research projects and presenting their work at conferences, students demonstrated enhanced confidence and competence in science, with 26 research presentations at scientific conferences and three published research manuscripts resulting from participants. These experiences prepared students not only for STEM careers but also for advanced studies and leadership roles.

Broader Impacts
The program made significant strides in fostering accessibility in STEM. Over five cohorts, all student participants were low-income, 55% of students were first-generation, and 33% were from underrepresented minority groups. Fellows also played an active role in encouraging others to pursue STEM through recruitment events and ambassador activities, leading to nearly a 10% increase in the yield of first-generation and low-income students accepted into the Freshman Research Initiative (FRI) program.

Community engagement was a hallmark of the program. Fellows initially planned to visit high schools to inspire future STEM students, but pandemic-related challenges led to a pivot toward virtual and on-campus outreach. Fellows created engaging scientific communication videos and participated in targeted recruitment events for underserved students. These activities reached broader audiences and demonstrated the adaptability and resilience of both students and program organizers.

Innovations and Institutional Impact
The program’s adaptability during the COVID-19 pandemic highlighted its innovative approach. For example, the UT Austin Undergraduate Research Forum, a key event for presenting student work, transitioned to a virtual format that increased accessibility for a larger audience, including industry professionals and the general public. This hybrid model is now a permanent feature of the event, expanding its reach and impact.

The program also influenced institutional practices at UT Austin, inspiring new initiatives for sophomore research support. Based on the success of the S-STEM Fellows, additional funding was secured to support low-income students in biodiversity-related research streams. Furthermore, work-study funding has been aligned to support S-STEM alumni in continuing mentorship roles, ensuring the sustainability of these impactful practices.

Conclusion
The S-STEM Sophomore Fellows Program has significantly advanced the goals of fostering student success, promoting accessibility in STEM, and preparing the next generation of scientists and innovators. By addressing critical barriers and creating a supportive academic environment, the program not only improved outcomes for participating students but also contributed to a more inclusive and effective model for STEM education. As these students advance in their careers, their achievements will continue to underscore the value of programs like this in building a stronger STEM workforce for the future.

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2025
Modified by: Kara Rogers
